title: How life-threatening brain tumour turned science teacher into beach eco warrior
text:

As a science teacher, Kiko Matthews was always fascinated by the world at large.

But it took a potentially deadly brain tumour to get the most out of life.

She became the fastest woman to row solo and unsupported across the Atlantic and has now taken on even bigger challenge.

The inspirational 38-year-old has cycled some 4,500 miles to help tidy up Britain’s plastic-ridden shoreline.

As she puts it: “I was given a second chance at life and I don’t want to waste it.”

Her epic green adventure took her around the entire UK coastline, including the northern part of Ireland.

On the way her project, The Kik-Plastic Challenge, has attracted 2,000 ­volunteers who have helped her clean 79 beaches.

Their painstaking searches of vast swathes of sand and pebbles, often in harsh weather, have turned up everything from drinking ­bottles to wet wipes and nylon fishing ropes.

She said: “We came away with nearly 3,500 tonnes and the amount of plastic we saw was just shocking.” On one beach alone they ­collected more than 600 plastic cable ties, used by the fishing industry.

She said: “In Edinburgh we found 120kg of wet wipes. Some brands say they are flushable but they don’t biodegrade at all. They come out of the sewers and end up back on the beaches.”

In northern Scotland they found up to 30 tonnes of fishing gear, including nylon rope. Plastic which gets blown inland endangers sheep if they eat it.

There is also the danger of micro-plastics, which break down into a powder that fish we eat may consume. Kiko said: “If everyone picked up just three bits of litter a day think what a better place our wildlife would be in.”

UK recycling company First Mile provided RecycleBoxes at each location for the waste which was sent to its lab for analysis.

Most commonly found were plastic bottles, tubs and cups followed by cans and glass. Yet 60 per cent of the rubbish collected could have been recycled.

The worst beach, aside from the one in northern Scotland, was Magilligan Point in Co Londonderry, Northern Ireland, where nearly 40st of beach waste was collected by just 12 ­volunteers.

About 85 per cent was fishing industry debris, such as ropes, nets and plastic containers.

The south and south-west coast beaches were the cleanest, with Minehead in Somerset and Budleigh Salterton in Devon the best. The clean up fits perfectly with Kiko’s motto: “living and ­giving”.

Last March she set a new record – as the ­fastest woman to row solo and unsupported across the Atlantic, in 49 days, 7 hours and 15 minutes.

(Image: Internet Unknown)

In doing so, she won the Pride of Britain’s Sporting Fundraiser of 2018 and raised nearly £100,000 for South London’s King’s College Hospital, where a medical team had saved her life.

Ten years ago Kiko’s dad suggested she go to the GP as she was experiencing bizarre symptoms, such as a metallic taste in her mouth.

She said: “I also felt odd in myself. I was away with the fairies half the time. I’d stopped sleeping properly and was alert and awake, brimming with ideas at 4am.”

She was also getting spots and putting on weight. Initially, after blood tests, she was diagnosed with diabetes.

She said: “My short-term memory was ­getting worse. In the supermarket I’d ­compare prices and forget what I’d just looked at.

“I was doing strange things. At one point I went online and bought my dad 88 light bulbs. Then I ordered lots of DVDs with French subtitles.”

Her mum, a nurse, started looking more closely at her symptoms and suggested she could have Cushing’s disease – a ­benign tumour of the pituitary gland in the brain.

Kiko said: “I had psychosis, skin-thinning, osteoporosis, I couldn’t walk upstairs unaided. Mum and I googled it together and all my symptoms were there. I couldn’t ­believe it.”

An MRI showed a 6mm brain tumour effecting her pituitary gland which was pumping out high levels of the ­hormone cortisol, hence her elevated mood and excess energy.

She was put on medicine to reduce hormone levels but while waiting surgery the potassium in her body plummeted. She went straight into intensive care.

She said: “I honestly thought I was ­going to die. They used a massive syringe which took seven different attempts to find a place to pump potassium back into my body.

“I went in for surgery –to have the ­tumour taken out through my nose.

“They started me on recovery meds after that and quite quickly everything started returning to normal.” The near-death ­experience led to the South Londoner re-evaluate her life and over the following two years.

In 2011 she quit her secondary school ­teaching job. She said: “I was passionate about science but I wasn’t loving it. I’d been given this second chance at life and I wanted whatever I did to help the planet and others.”

(Image: PA Wire/PA Images)

She set up Trash4Treats, a campaign that encouraged paddle boarders to clear litter from London’s Regent’s Canal.

In 2016, pal Charlie Pitcher who, at the time, held the men’s solo record for ­rowing the Atlantic, ­suggested she have a bash at the women’s record. Kiko started training but six months before the challenge she had to have a second tumour removed.

She said: “I ­realise now the tumour returning had sent me loopy again and all that confidence and ­excess energy that went into the rowing ­challenge was because of my hormones. Strangely, probably wouldn’t have decided to do it but for the tumour.”

On the crossing, she barely ate due to nausea. She took 50 days of food, and landed in Barbados with 27 days worth left. She said she struggles to remember the ­experience.

Last year Kiko, who is currently staying on friends’ sofas, started planning her beach clean-up. The ex-molecular biology student used her rowing success to get firms to sponsor her trip and arrange their own beach clean-ups.

(Image: Â©Todd-White Art Photography 2019)

She kipped in a friend’s end-of-garden London cabin to save pennies, then crammed all her possessions into the back of a van and set off around Britain on her bike. Kind-hearted locals helped put her up in some places.

She said: “One woman let me sleep in this amazing glass dome she had in her garden. Other times we camped or local hotels put us up.”

Kiko’s already planning the next beach clean-up – and it’s even bigger than this one. “I want to clean up beaches from London to Monaco via Gibraltar next.

“I don’t have check-ups anymore. I sometimes look at myself if I’ve put on weight and think, ‘is that my diet or the Cushing’s coming back?’ but I’d rather fill my days doing something positive.”

“I hope I inspire people and bring awareness of what we can all do as ­individuals to help the world.”

For more information about Kiko and First Mile visit Kikomatthews.co.uk and recyclebox.co.uk

About RecycleBox

RecycleBox has been developed by First Mile to help the UK reach its recycling targets and overcome its stagnant household recycling rates.

RecycleBox offers consumers and businesses an easy and low-cost recycling post-back service aimed at those that want to do their bit for the environment.

The box is a recycling solution for many items not collected in traditional household recycling or waste collection schemes, such as compostable packaging, coat hangers, shoes and coffee pods.
